Chapter.Section:
Wedderburn decomposition
a list of simple algebras as GAP objects
Computes the list of Wedderburn components of a group algebra FG realizable by strongly Shoda pairs of G. The input FG should be a group ring over a finite group G with coefficients in F, where F is either the field Q of rationals or a finite field whose characteristic is coprime with the order of G. In many cases every Wedderburn component of FG is realizable by a strongly Shoda pair of the direct product of the entries of the output is isomorphic to FG. For example these is the case if G is abelian-by-supersolvable .
gap> FD16:=GroupRing(GF(5),DihedralGroup(16)); <algebra-with-one over GF(5), with 4 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition(FD16); [ GF(5), GF(5), GF(5), GF(5), ( GF(5)^[ 2, 2 ] ), ( GF(5^2)^[ 2, 2 ] ) ]
The previous example shows that the Wedderburn decomposition of the group algebra GF(5)D_{16} of the dihedral group of order 16 over the field of order 5 is 4GF(5)\oplus M_2(GF(5)) \oplus M_2(GF(25)). Next example shows the Wedderburn decomposition of the rational group algebra of the symmetric group on 4 letters.
gap> QS4:=GroupRing(Rationals,SymmetricGroup(4)); <algebra-with-one over Rationals, with 2 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition(QS4); [ Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), <crossed product over CF(3), with 2 generators> ]
If not all the Wedderburn components of input are realizable by strongly Shoda pairs then a warning message is displayed together with the output.
gap> G:=SmallGroup(24,3);QG:=GroupRing(Rationals,G); <pc group of size 24 with 4 generators> <algebra-with-one over Rationals, with 4 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition(QG); Warning!!! Some primitive central idempotents are not realizable by strongly Shoda pairs!!! [ Rationals, CF(3), ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ) ]
a list of descriptions of simple algebras (not as GAP objects)
Computes some numerical data that describes the Wedderburn components of a group algebra FG realizable by strongly Shoda pairs of G. The interprestion of the information displayed by the output is explained in . The input FG should be as in and the output represent the information describing the simple algebras given as output by .
gap> F:=FreeGroup("a","b");;a:=F.1;;b:=F.2;;rel:=[a^8,a^4*b^2,b^-1*a*b*a];;G:=F/rel; <fp group on the generators [ a, b ]> gap> QG:=GroupRing(Rationals,G);WedderburnDecomposition(QG); <algebra-with-one over Rationals, with 2 generators> [ Rationals, Rationals, Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 2, 2 ] ), <crossed product over CF(8), with 2 generators> ] gap> WedderburnDecompositionInfo(QG); [ [ 1, 1, [ ], [ ] ], [ 1, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 1, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 1, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 2, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 1, 8, [ [ 2, 7, 4 ] ], [ ] ] ]
In the previous example one has computed the Wedderburn decomposition of the rational group algebra QG of the quaternion group of order 16 by using and . The first 4 Wedderburn components are isomorphic to the field Q of rationals numbers and the fourth one is isomorphic to M_2(Q). The last one is a crossed product with coefficients in Q(\xi), where \xi is a complex 8-th root of the unity. While the output of does not give precise information on the data describing this crossed product the output of shows that this algebra is given by the following presentation (see ):
Q(\xi)[g | \xi^g = \xi^{-1}, g^2 = \xi^4 = -1]

ManSection.Description:
The versions with three input data computes the Wedderburn component of the rational group algebra QG of a finite group G realized by a strongly Shoda pair (K,H) of G (see Section ).
The versions with four input data computes the Wedderburn component of the semisimple finite group algebra FG realized by a strongly Shoda pair (K,H) of G and a q-cyclotom class C (see Section ).
